item.content:encoded:
The Building is actually two separate buildings, and one of the things that’s happening this week is that we’re knocking out a section of the wall to create an opening between the two spaces.

 
 
 
This is no small feat, as there’s a thick rock wall between them.

 
 
 
I spy the other side!

 
 
 
Here’s a closer look.

Now. I’d better move before plaster falls on my head.

 
 
 
This is the view from the other direction. In this space I’m standing, we’re going to do…well, the closest description I can give you is a deli. Not a restaurant, but a deli. A deli…concept.

But it’s more than a deli! But it’s definitely not a restaurant! Makes perfect sense, right?

Ha.

Anyway, I’ll explain it in more detail later. Let’s just say I’m excited about it because it involves food. It’s going to be a place where people can hang and eat food…or take food with them…or stay and play a round of laser tag.

(Just kidding on the laser tag part.)

 
 
 
Then there’s the upstairs space, which is divided into two sides: The north side and the south side. This is the north side…

 
 
 
And it’ll be our office. Ranch office, P-Widdy Dub Diddy office, homeschool space for the kids, a place to meet in town that doesn’t involve someone having to travel five miles down a gravel road. Tim, Marlboro Man, my father-in-law, and I will share it. I’ll put fresh daisies in vases on their desks every day.

Or…not.

 
 
 
This is the wall directly above the wall they’re tearing down on the first floor. Originally, Marlboro Man and I had planned to open up this wall, too, so the two upstairs spaces would have the same opening. But now that we’ve thought about it, since the space on this side will be just an office, we don’t need a huge opening between the two spaces. So we’re leaving this wall as is. This makes me happy, because it’s the original exterior wall of the south building and still has an old advertising mural.

I had great angst about tearing it down.

 
 
 
This is the other side of the wall.

 
 
 
I love it up here—the south side, upstairs. We’re still deciding/refining how this space will be used, but I’ll keep you posted.

(Hint: It’s not a dance studio. I’d have to wear a leotard, which rules that out instantly.)

 
 
 
Most of the floors in The Building are going to be able to be saved, but in this particular room, they’re warped and a little past the point of no return.

 
 
 
I wonder what happened here? A bar fight? Rabid raccoons? Velociraptors?

Anytime I see a scratch on anything, I immediately think of Velociraptors. I saw Jurassic Park 93 times.

 
 
 
Speaking of not having a dance studio in the upstairs space: Name that ballet position!

 
 
 
Throughout the building, we’re having to decide where to strip away the old plaster and expose the original brick and where to patch and re-plaster. In most every room, there’s going to wind up being a mix of plaster and brick…depending, well, on the current condition of the plaster and the brick.

 
 
 
We have most of the original trim: window trim, baseboards, etc. We’re taking good care of it and will put it back once everything else is done.

 
 
 
These window frames will go to Missouri soon, just after the next batch of windows comes back.

 
 
 
Meanwhile, back in the office space (Get it? Office Space? “Well, I wouldn’t exactly say I’ve been missing it, Bob.”) This is where the bathrooms will go upstairs, and there’ll also be doors from the other side so they can be accessed from there. And the bathrooms downstairs will be directly below these—which, obviously, makes more sense from a plumbing perspective.

 
 
 
The floors in the office are, by and large, in great shape. We’ll just lightly sand and refinish these—gouges and all!

(This place was totally overrun with velociraptors before we got a hold of it.)

 
 
 
Downstairs, here are a bunch of the ceiling tiles from the north side. They’re all ready to be stripped.

 
 
 
And downstairs in the south side, we’re hard at work on what will happen in there.

 
 
 
Which takes us back to the wall at the end of that room: By the time we left yesterday, it was really starting to come down.

I’ll drop by today and see how far they got.

item.content:encoded:
While transferring images from one of my camera cards the other day, I came across these photos.

 
 
 
I didn’t take them. My boys did. My older son was behind the camera, while my younger son was doing an interpretive dance across the kitchen.

 
 
 
I think he’s wearing underwear.

Nice touch, don’t you think?

 
 
 
Actually, I should probably give thanks he’s wearing underwear.

Always look at the bright side of life.

 
 
 
Anyway, I find series of photos like these all the time. I never know when they were taken or why.

I just know I had nothing to do with them.

 
 
 
The kid’s got moves. I’ll give him that.

Takes after his mother.

Ahem.

Oh, and then there’s Instagram. Over the past week, the hackers have both used my phone to Instagram photos of themselves.

 
 
There’s this one.

I was downstairs.

 
 
 
And this one.

I was in the next room.

And then…there’s this one.

 
Bruiser!!! You too???

I’ll have to keep a closer eye on that little pookie.

item.content:encoded:
Raise your hand if you love potato skins.

ME ME ME ME ME ME ME ME ME ME!

Okay, so I think I’ve established that I love potato skins. I can’t help it, man. They’re just so 1984! And everything that’s 1984 is okay by me. Except tanning beds. *Shudder* But that’s another story for another time.

Usually when I make potato skins, I go old school and top them with melted cheddar, diced bacon, sour cream, and chives. But there are so many variations on the theme. Pizza, for instance! Imagine the possibilities. I whipped up these very simple pepperoni pizza beauties, but you can take off running and do whatever pizza topping makes your skirt fly up. So many possiblities!

 
To make the potato skins, scrub the heck out of some small russet potatoes in order to get them nice and clean. When they’re dry, brush the whole surface of the potatoes with a little canola or olive oil.

 
 
 
Sprinkle them with a little kosher salt, then put them in a 400 degree oven for about 30-45 minutes. You want the potatoes to be nice and tender, and you want the skin to be a little on the crisp side. The baking time will be determined by the size of the ‘taters, so just give ‘em a squeeze after 30-35 minutes (with a towel in your hand, of course! ha.) and monitor them till they’re done.

 
 
 
They’re done now. Nice and tender. Nice and (somewhat) crispy skin. So split them in half…

 
 
 
And use a spoon to scoop out the potato, leaving a little bit of a rim (for support) all the way around.

 
 
 
Like this!

 
 
 
Now, melt a little butter and brush it really lightly on the inside of the potato…

 
 
 
And the outside, too!

 
 
 
Then put them back in the oven: First put them in skin side up for about 5-7 minutes…then use tongs to flip them over and put them back in the oven for a few more minutes, or until they’re nice and crisp and wonderful.

 
 
 
Meanwhile, dice up some pepperoni. I used this whole piece, which was easy to dice up—but you can buy the sliced stuff and dice it up, too.

 
 
 
Grate up some mozzarella, too! (You can use the good, fresh stuff if you have it. I done didn’t have it. I mean I didn’t done have it. Oh, never mind.)

 
 
 
Finally, crack open a jar of the hard stuff!

I mean the jarred stuff.

And yes. You can make your own marinara sauce if you druther.

But this day, I just didn’t druther.

And you know what? The next time I make it, I probably won’t druther neither.

 
 
To build the skins, spoon a little bit of pizza sauce into each skin.

 
 
 
Sprinkle on a good amount of grated mozzarella…

 
 
 
And some diced pepperoni.

Then put them back in the oven for 3 to 5 minutes, until the cheese melts and everything’s hot and bubbly.

 
 
 
Sprinkle on some minced parsley right when they come out of the oven…

 
 
 
And serve ‘em up!

You’ll love these. So easy…so tasty. And considering the pizza topping possibilities that exist in this universe of ours, you could have a whole party based on pizza potato skin variations alone. Here are some other ideas:

Crumbled cooked Italian sausage
Crumbled cooked hamburger
Diced red, green, or yellow bell pepper
Diced red onion
Sliced black olives
Sliced jalapenos
Diced Canadian bacon
Pineapple
Sliced or diced mushrooms
All different cheeses

Have fun with these!

Here’s the handy dandy printable:

Recipe

Pizza Potato Skins

Prep Time:
10 Minutes
Cook Time:
20 Minutes
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
16
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 8 whole Small Russet Potatoes
  • Canola Oil
  • Butter, Melted
  • Kosher Salt
  • Jarred Marinara Or Pizza Sauce
  • Grated Mozzarella Cheese
  • Diced Pepperoni
  • Minced Fresh Parsley
  • Miscellaneous Pizza Toppings: Cooked Sausage, Cooked Hamburger, Diced Bell Pepper, Diced Onion, Diced Mushrooms, Diced Canadian Bacon, Etc.

Preparation Instructions

Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Scrub potatoes very clean.

Rub the surface of each potato with canola oil. Sprinkle with salt and bake until the potatoes are tender and the skins are crisp, about 30 to 45 minutes.

Cut the baked potatoes in half, then use a spoon to scoop out most of the insides, leaving a bit of a rim all around. Brush the inside and outside of each half with melted butter. Place the potatoes skin side up and return to the oven for 5 to 7 minutes. Turn them over (using tongs) and put them back in the oven for a few more minutes, or until the potatoes are crisp. Remove them from the oven and set them aside.

To assemble the skins, fill each skin with a spoonful of marinara or pizza sauce. Add a good amount of grated cheese and sprinkle on some diced pepperoni. Return them to the oven for just a couple of minutes, or until the cheese is melted.

Sprinkle with minced parsley and serve immediately!

Posted by Ree on April 4 2013

Rather than do what I normally do when I’m faced with comparison photos such as these—which is cry, wail, weep, freak out, wig out, pass out, sob and stomp my feet over how quickly time is passing and how much my children have grown—I’m going to conduct a healthy exercise and instead…
item.content:encoded:
This photo was taken seven years ago.

 
 
 
This photo was taken Sunday.

You know what? I just had a revelation. Rather than do what I normally do when I’m faced with comparison photos such as these—which is cry, wail, weep, freak out, wig out, pass out, sob and stomp my feet over how quickly time is passing and how much my children have grown—I’m going to conduct a healthy exercise and instead smile, appreciate the fact that my children are older, wiser, and more learned now, and cherish the time I have left with them before they leave the house to move on with their adult lives.

Deep breath: In…out.

Ahhh. You know what? I actually feel better!

See, that wasn’t so bad. I’ve learned I don’t have to wail and cry when I look at old photos of my children. I’ve learned I don’t have to mourn the fact that they’re no longer babies. I’ve learned I don’t have to pitch a fit at the prospect of them growing up!

I feel so cleansed. I feel so healthy. I feel so whole!

 
 
But…just wook at their wittle faces. My younger daughter’s short little haircut. My little blond boy’s cherubic cheeks. And just look how teeny tiny my baby was. And my older daughter…just look at what a sweet little pookie love she was…

Okay. I’m now officially in a spiral.

So much for conducting healthy exercises!

item.content:encoded:
By Heather Sanders.

Homeschooling conventions are a tremendous source of inspiration and encouragement, but if families are not prepared, they can also be an equal source of stress. As Henry Ford said, “Before everything else, getting ready is the secret to success.” The following 5 suggestions will help you successfully navigate your next homeschool convention.

1. Pre-Register to Save Money and Time

Most homeschool conventions offer pre-registration. The convention we attend offers the best discounts for early-bird registration, but even after that deadline, pre-registration is available until about 6 weeks prior to the event.

Pre-registering is especially advantageous if the entire family wants to take part in all the activities offered. Because of the planning and staffing required to run the children’s and teen’s programs, conventions do not usually allow on-site registration for these programs on the date of the event.

Since the workshops are geared toward parents, and not all conventions allow children to be present in the adult workshops, the children’s and teen’s programs offer an entertaining, age-appropriate alternative.

An additional perk to early registration is avoiding long lines on the day of the event. Pre-registering gives you a fast pass into the event. Event coordinators and volunteers work diligently for days prior to the event to pull registration bags together, print name tags, string lanyards, sort t-shirts, and whatever else is required for those families they know will attend.

2. Reserve Hotel Rooms or Make Arrangements to Stay with Friends or Family

Depending on the size of the homeschool convention that you attend, there may be significant discounts for convention attendees in nearby hotels. Even without convention discounts, hotels in the surrounding area will likely fill up fast. The earlier rooms are reserved, the better the rate. As the event nears the likelihood of finding a room in a nearby hotel, or one at a reasonable rate, will become few and far between.

If staying with friends or family, it is crucial to get the convention dates blocked-out on both family’s calendars, so no one is unpleasantly surprised when the date of the event arrives.

3. Study the Event Schedule, Speakers, and Workshops

The convention we attend is always the first weekend in August, and the basic schedule has been consistent every year we’ve attended.

As the date of the event draws nearer, the convention will release an extended schedule with details about every workshop and speaker, including the day, room and time they will speak. Once this is available, I print it out, and Jeff and I review it together, making decisions how we will tackle the convention.

There are many times we go to workshops or speakers together (especially the Keynote Speakers’ break-out sessions), but other times we are interested in two different workshops going on at the same time, so we split up, taking notes for each other.

Though there have been times we changed our mind at the last minute, we like to go into the convention with a plan. Homeschooling conventions are crowded and hectic, having a tentative plan in hand brings a bit of order to the chaos.

4. Don’t Enter the Exhibit Hall Without a Plan

The exhibit hall is usually the most exciting and simultaneously daunting place in the entire convention. Our convention hosts literally hundreds of vendors with elaborate booths set up to display homeschool curricula and services.

I always recommend parents not to enter the exhibit hall without a plan, especially if this is their first year to homeschool.

Following the last week of each school year, the kids and I review what worked and what did not work for us in our homeschool. With their feedback, I make decisions about the upcoming year. I make a list of the things I will need, compare it against what I have boxed up in the attic, or what I can borrow from friends, and then I make a list of what needs to be purchased.

If I can purchase these items at a reasonable rate, free of shipping, before the convention, I do. However, I know that vendors at the convention offer discounts, as well as free shipping, so if I think I can get a better rate there, I will wait.

I enter the exhibit hall with a list of what I need, along with the comparable pricing. This makes it easy to decide whether or not I will purchase while at the convention.

In addition, if I have a wish list or I want to “see” something I have heard about, I’ll seek out that booth.

And finally, I bring a bit of extra cash if I believe I may be interested in any of the offerings from the workshops I plan to attend.

Last year I spent $98 at the convention; I purchased from only one vendor. However, I saw many things I was interested in purchasing, but knew I didn’t need.

5. Look Up, Smile, Meet People, and Share!

Homeschooling conventions range in size. We attend the THSC Southwest Convention & Family Conference, and it is enormous. I make it a point to look up, smile, talk with people when I’m in line, meet people to the left and right of me when I’m sitting in a session, or ask people questions. This is one of the most fun parts of attending a homeschooling convention – being surrounded by tons and tons of like-minded parents. It is a tremendous experience!

I have never been snubbed at a homeschooling convention. No one has ever looked the other way and ignored me. Not surprisingly to most women who will read this, but some of the best conversations I’ve had have been in line for the bathroom.

Not sure how to start a conversation? Ask a parent about their kids. “How many children do you have?”, “What are their ages?”, “How long have you been homeschooling?” These are all engaging conversation starters, and who knows, you may find a new friend.

I like to take cards to pass out with my name, email and blog URL. If you are a homeschooling blogger, homeschooling conferences are ideal places to get to know someone online and off.

One Last Thing…
I always take a clipboard with looseleaf notebook paper and a pen. I know some people prefer spiral bound notebooks, but I’m a gal who loves a clipboard. Whatever you do, make sure you have a hard surface for taking notes because most of the rooms provide row after row of chairs, but no tables, desks, or other hard surfaces to write on.

For those who are planning to traverse their very first convention, I’m extremely excited for you! For those who have attended for years, or are actively involved in planning their local convention, please feel free to offer your own sage advice in the comments.

Are you planning on attending a homeschool convention this year? If so, let us know which one in the comments. Include any other helpful information for families who may be attending their first!

 

Heather Sanders is a leading homeschooling journalist who inspires homeschooling families across the nation. Married to Jeff, Heather lives in the East Texas Piney Woods and homeschools her three children, Emelie, Meredith and Kenny.

item.content:encoded:
The boys woke up early yesterday morning because they couldn’t wait to get all spiffed up for church. They love getting dressed up; have I ever told you this? They willingly go shopping for clothes when the need arises and nothing makes them happier than putting on a pair of pants and a nice shirt and looking all dapper.

I’m 100% convinced this is the direct result of the fact that they live on a cattle ranch and have been coated in mud and manure for approximately 87% of their lives.

I put together Easter baskets for the kids because it’s a tradition, and if I suspend any of these traditions it means my kids are too old for those traditions, and from there it’s just a slippery slope until they’re grown and gone and cobwebs form in my hair.

Here’s what I put in each basket:

* 1 small stuffed animal.
* 1 pair of sunglasses, which I propped on the face of each small stuffed animal.
* 1 OKC Thunder t-shirt. Because Thunder Up. That’s why.
* 1 Cadbury Creme Egg
* Minus 1 Cadbury Creme Egg, because I ate one of the eggs Saturday night and decided to be fair, I needed to remove the rest of the eggs. And hide them in my bedside table.
* 1 pair of flip flops. Perfect for our gravel roads!
* Lots of miscellaneous candy.
* Minus some of the miscellaneous candy.

It was a Walmart kinda Easter!

Then we went to church and it was beautiful.

There’s so much I love about Easter.

 
 
After church we went to Tim and Missy’s house for our big traditional Easter meal.

Ham, you ask?

Well…

Not exactly.

 
 
 
Steaks! For Easter brunch! What’s the world coming to?

 
 
 
Don’t ask. Long story.

 
 
 
In addition to some delicious sides, we also had this cake, which we decided to name “Earthquake Cake.”

Don’t ask. Long story.

 
 
 
Missy’s always wearing pretty earrings.

Don’t ask. Long story.

Not really. I just felt like saying it again.

 
 
 
After lunch, the kids played basketball.

 
 
 
Aw, my sweet baby and my sweet niece. They have so much fun together!

 
 
 
At least…at least I think they have fun together.

 
 
 
Um…is everything okay over there?

 
 
 
Yes, Aunt Ree—everything’s great!

Okay, just checking/

 
 
So then, Missy, my mother-in-law, and Edna Mae (Marlboro Man’s grandmother) and I found ourselves sitting in the dining room and visiting about the old days. Edna Mae talked about the days when she used to have a wood burning stove, and she’d cook a huge breakfast and lunch every day for her husband and ranch workers, and after lunch was over she’d do the dishes with her two daughters, then she’d pass out from exhaustion while they went swimming in the water hole.

She also talked about the time before she was married when she and her best friend would saddle their horses and ride seven miles to town to the drugstore, where they’d spend all their money (probably twenty cents between them) on sodas because the soda jerk (that’s what they used to call people who made the soda drinks) was a really cute and nice fella.

Then they’d ride home seven miles, giggling and recounting all the conversation they’d just had with the cute and nice soda jerk.

Oh, how I love Edna Mae. This Saturday’s Food Network episode is all about her. It’s one of my favorites so far.

My mother-in-law talked about the old days, too—about her childhood in the country, about her propensity for finding quiet plots of pasture and lying down with her Border Collie and gazing at the sky, and about the early days of her marriage, when she hardly saw Marlboro Man’s dad because they didn’t have horse trailers back then and he’d have to sometimes leave at three in the morning to ride his horse to the place he needed to go, and he sometimes wouldn’t get home till nine at night.

 
 
Missy and I talked about the old days, too.

But it was about things like how Walmart was just Walmart back when we were kids.

Not Walmart Supercenter.

 
 
And my mother-in-law laughed…which I think is when she is at her most beautiful.

Fortunately for her, she laughs all the time!

item.content:encoded:
Got leftover Easter eggs?

Got leftover Easter ham?

Got a hearty appetite?

Good! You’ve come to the right place!

I made this big honkin’ sandwich a few months ago, and it’ll be in my holiday cookbook, which is coming this fall assuming I finish said holiday cookbook. Whee! Oh, and I’d better go cook now.

Anyway, as I’ve explained to you before, it’s very difficult for me to save recipes for my cookbooks and not share them here. It’s a clinical affliction known as Saverecipesformycookbookitis.

I’ve got a wicked case of it, man.

 
First of all, have you ever done this? If not, get ready to be inspired to make egg salad every day for the rest of your life. Peel your hard-boiled eggs and place it on top of a cooling rack you’d use for cookies or cakes. (The rack should be resting over a bowl.)

 
 
 
Use the palm of your (very clean) hand and pop it right through!

 
 
 
Then just keep doing it egg by egg…

 
 
 
Until you have a bowl full of perfectly “chopped up” eggs.

 
 
 
Add mayonnaise, grainy mustard, Worcestershire, salt, and pepper. You can also add chopped up pickles, olives, splash in a little pickle juice, Sriracha, Tabasco…anything you want to give it the flavor you’re lookin’ for.

 
 
 
Stir it together, making sure to taste and adjust seasonings to make sure it’s just right!

 
 
 
To build the sandwich, halve the bread of your choice (I used a Kaiser roll) and spread one half with Dijon…

 
 
 
Then spread the other half with mayonnaise and sprinkle it with salt and pepper.

 
 
 
On the half with the Dijon, lay a slice of cheese. I used Swiss.

 
 
 
Then lay on some of the leftover Easter ham.

 
 
 
Meanwhile, on the mayo half, lay a bunch of luscious avocado pieces…

 
 
 
And a few very thin slices of red onion, as well as two or three slices of Roma tomato, which I don’t have a photo of, because I’m an airhead.

 
 
 
Grab a big scoop of egg salad…

 
 
 
Plop it on top of the tomatoes…

 
 
 
And spread it out into an even layer.

 
 
 
Finally, lay on whatever lettuce or greens you have: green leaf, Romaine, or just mixed greens. Spinach or arugula would also be divine!

 
 
 
Then take a deep breath and put the two halves together.

 
 
 
Serve it with chips…and a very, very, very, very, very big appetite.

Here’s the handy printable. I hope you all had a wonderful weekend!

 

Recipe

Leftover Easter Sandwich

Prep Time:
15 Minutes
Cook Time:
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
8
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 12 whole Hard Boiled Eggs
  • 1/2 cup Mayonnaise
  • 3 Tablespoons Grainy Dijon Mustard
  • Salt And Pepper, to taste
  • Several Dashes Worcestershire Sauce
  • Leftover Baked Ham, Sliced
  • Kaiser Rolls Or Other Bread
  • Extra Mayonnaise And Dijon, For Spreading
  • Swiss Cheese Or Other Cheese Slices
  • Thinly Sliced Red Onion
  • Avocado Slices
  • Sliced Tomatoes
  • Lettuce, Spinach, Or Arugula

Preparation Instructions

Make egg salad by chopping the hard boiled eggs and mixing in a bowl with mayonnaise, Dijon, salt and pepper, Worcestershire (and you can also add chopped pickles, hot sauce, etc.) Taste and adjust seasonings.

Halve the rolls and spread one half with Dijon, the other half with mayonnaise. Sprinkle the mayonnaise-spread half with salt and pepper. Lay cheese and ham on the mustard half; lay avocado, onion slices, tomato slices, egg salad, and lettuce on the other half.

Bring the two halves together and chow down!

Variation: Add bacon! Yes, I said it.

While we like the school, and have no problem with them per se, we feel that he is not challenged enough. I should also add that my son is advanced, learning to read in just 2 months at age 4, and is a self-motivated learner. Up until this point we have really only introduced subjects to him (math, science, the dinosaurs, etc…), and then let him loose with a book.

item.content:encoded:
The new windows have been coming in in batches of ten, and it’s so exciting to watch them go in. You can see in this photo that the run of windows along the right side of the building have been replaced. The ones on the side of the building facing us…well, not so much.

But soon.

 
 
 
These’ll be coming next, and I can’t wait to see ‘em. I love this part of the building.

 
 
 
Here’s the view from Main Street.

 
 
 
Brent was hard at work sealing the windows yesterday.

 
 
 
These were the windows in the back of the building in February.

 
 
 
This is the view from the alley now. We started back there and are working our way around. The windows get taken out and hauled to Missouri in groups of ten…then come back some time later.

 
 
 
As I explained here, we aren’t replacing with brand new windows; we’re having the old ones redone. Once they make it back here, Terry’s crew is wrapping the woodwork in metal to make them ultra-durable.

 
 
 
Here’s a slightly closer look (I’ll try to get some process shots of the guys covering the windows when the next batch comes in.) Most of the frame is wrapped in metal; the only thing they’re having to paint is the sash around the glass.

That’ll save us a lot of maintenance down the line.

 
 
 
This is the west side of the building. There’ll be lots to do here: Windows, of course, but then we’ll remove the huge awning (it’s on its last leg), blast the green paint off the brick, and redo the fronts of the two spaces.

And take a nap every now and then.

 
 
 
It’s fun to see the windows on the outside…but it’s even better to see how it transforms the inside. This is the upstairs space a year or so ago.

 
 
 
And here it is with the new windwos.

 
 
 
This room hasn’t seen this much light in…well, 40 years? 50 years? More?

 
 
 
And in this corner of the other room next door…

 
 
 
Let there be light!

In other news, a wall is coming down next week. I’ll share all the dusty details then.

Love,
P-Widdy

We had a busy day in the big city yesterday that involved a soccer game, an action movie, and Easter dress shopping with two teenage girls over 5’11″.

Which one of these three things do you think ended in tears?

 
 
Anyway, we were all ready for a peaceful Good Friday on the ranch today.

 
 
 
Peaceful, of course, doesn’t necessarily mean there isn’t work to do.

 
 
 
There are some cattle to gather this morning.

 
 
 
The animals on the ranch don’t observe holidays.

 
 
 
Marlboro Man observes holidays. After the animals are taken care of.

 
 
 
So after the cattle are gathered…

 
 
 
And the work is done for the day…

 
 
 
We’re going to settle in and enjoy the rest of our day together.

 
 
 
Maybe make some Hot Cross Buns.

 
 
 
Maybe boil the eggs for dyeing tomorrow.

 
 
 
Maybe go up against mom in a round or two of Just Dance 3.

She beat everyone last time. Creamed ‘em, actually.

That mom. She’s got moves like no other!

 
 
 
“Emphasis on ‘like no other.’”

Ahem.

Have a very blessed Good Friday, friends.

Lots of love,
P-Dub

item.content:encoded:
By Heather Sanders.

Yesterday, I spent an entire morning and early afternoon catching up with my closest friend and confidante, Cindy. Together we serve on the board of our local homeschool cooperative, plan and attend field trips, scrutinize and select curriculum and discuss our daily homeschooling challenges. She is a certified teacher and a phenomenal listener, and I am certifiably annoying, and an avid talker, so we balance beautifully.

Outside of my family, she is probably my biggest fan, but recently confessed she does not actually read my posts, “But I always look at the pictures”, she emphatically proclaimed. I quickly forgave her because I know that by the time I muster the words to post she has heard them at least a half-dozen times, tossed out in far too many theoretical arguments for her to have to read them again. God bless her because yesterday’s conversation was no different.

After reading all the comments about homeschooling styles in last week’s post, I want to talk about my favorite new brain drain, Unschooling, or rather, how, or if, parents should play a role in shaping what they teach, and their children learn.

I am in the process of working through my own thoughts regarding the whole Structured Homeschooling versus Unschooling conundrum. I don’t think it is a black and white issue; it appears that, just as with homeschooling, there are all different shades of grey between the two.

Here are the questions I’m knocking around in my head this week. Feel free to respond to any one of them, or all of them, in the comments below.

1. Is structure necessary for the early elementary years?

It was my experience that all three of my children loved having books read to them from an early age. Jeff and I took turns reading their favorite stories over and over until they could recite them from memory while running their pudgy little fingers under the words across the page.

While I remember pointing out letter names and sounds, the basic 3-letter words seemed to progress naturally; however, when the kids advanced to sight words there was considerably more work involved for all of us. I made up games and activities to help memorize the words, and soon we began stringing words together in sentences. At times, they were frustrated or bored, but then they would have what I call “break through moments”, when they would shine with pride at what they just achieved or understood.

The same thing was true with Math. In the beginning, it was easy to show them that when they had one block, and added one more, then they had two blocks. As the concepts built on each other, so have the challenges.

While I understand that the philosophy behind Unschooling is to set the stage for natural learning to thrive, I am not certain most kids would decide to memorize sight words in Kindergarten, or later on, to memorize their multiplication tables. Perhaps Unschooled parents lean on some subjects more than others? Most Unschooling families I am exposed to do not purchase a set curriculum. Is the idea to surround one’s children with more interest led subject matter that points to reading, writing and math? If there is not a set structure I am curious what learning looks like, and how parents can be certain the foundation is laid.

2. Is testing necessary at any point?

Until we joined our local homeschool cooperative, I never formally tested my children or applied grades on anything they learned. I was fully aware of their level of learning as we worked together. If I felt a concept was dropped, we reviewed back over it until it was clear.

In the back of my head, I figured I would be forced to grade once they reached their high school years in order to build an honest transcript, and I left it at that.

I’m not sure that is relevant to Unschooling, but it certainly is a radical off-shoot from the Structured Homeschooling approach.

It wasn’t that testing scared me–I just didn’t find it necessary. Some people say that testing is just a means to stroke parent egos, as opposed to accessing true knowledge and understanding. I schooled my children at home, and there was not a need to compare my children to others. I simply focused on teaching them, and as they grew in maturity, I showed them how to find the resources they needed to learn on their own.

Now that my older daughter is finishing up her Sophomore year, we have an established transcript with grades. With all the research about testing, it becomes more and more obvious that test grades are not necessarily the Holy Grail of true understanding or intelligence. So, why do we test and keep grades?

I keep them out of fear of somehow limiting her potential future. The world is changing, and Emelie is not at all interested in pursuing academia through a 4-year university, but I still keep those high school grades just in case. Maybe mine will be the last generation that frets over their children’s test scores and transcripts.

3. If parents don’t set expectations for learning, will kids grow to respect and meet the expectations of others?

Who we become as adults is directly affected by the family culture we grew up in. I realize that there are exceptions to every rule, but for the most part, there are many things that carry through from one generation to the next. Though our very nature is ingrained, there are aspects of how we are nurtured in our childhood that play out in how we relate to others in our adult life, specifically others who are in a position of authority over us.

If as parents, we do not set expectations for learning for our children, and if they get to decide what they want to learn and when they want to learn it, is there a valid argument that says they will have difficulty meeting the expectations of future bosses?

On one hand, I want to say that the freedom to choose one’s own learning path is unrelated to whether or not we will be able to submit to another’s expectations in the future. Perhaps the single act of a parent respecting a child’s right to their own learning leaves the child emotionally stable enough not to cultivate a spirit of rebellion that would cause them to rebuff the expectations of a supervisor later on in life.

Then again, if we never require our children to meet any standard that they don’t set for themselves, will they become overly egocentric, believing the world revolves around them? Do we inadvertently set them up for failure by freeing them from failure in the early years?

At this point, it might be readily obvious why Cindy is such a good friend for me. She lends an ear to all my mind’s inner ramblings, quietly taking them in and processing them as I toss more and more her way.

I know one thing, if I had been Unschooled, I would need a strong visionary to guide me out of the murky bog because I get fixated with all the details. I used to believe Unschooling was taking the easy way out – I was wrong. It is much easier to follow the old school rules of engagement. We have to ask ourselves whether or not those rules are the most effective approach for today’s world.

Now it’s your turn. How, or do you, shape what you teach your children?

 

Heather Sanders is a leading homeschooling journalist who inspires homeschooling families across the nation. Married to Jeff, Heather lives in the East Texas Piney Woods and homeschools her three children, Emelie, Meredith and Kenny.

item.content:encoded:
I think you’ll love this colorful, pretty fruit salad, which is drizzled with a lovely orange-vanilla syrup, which glosses it up and makes it visually irresistible, which makes you want to stand over the bowl and slurp up every single bite, which won’t leave any for your brunch guests.

So logic would probably tell you not not to make it.

But I think you should go ahead and chance it! It’s that good. Slightly citrusy, nice and sweet, with a little hint of vanilla lusciousness. So simple to make, and you can use any fruit you want—melon chunks, orange pieces, apples, pears…the works. And it’s perfect not just for Easter brunch, but for baby or wedding showers, special lunches…or just a weekday that calls for a beautiful bowl of color.

Here’s how to make it, Maynard!

Sorry I called you Maynard again.

Next year I’ll give it up for Lent. Promise.

 
Add sugar and water to a small saucepan…

 
 
 
Then zest a juicy orange and add the zest to the pan…

 
 
 
Then cut the orange in half…

 
 
 
And squeeze the juice into the pan.

 
 
 
Slice two vanilla beans in half…

 
 
 
Then scrape out the caviar inside…

 
 
 
And add it to the saucepan. Yum!

(Note: You can just add 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract if you don’t have vanilla beans. Still delicious!)

 
 
 
Stir it around and bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce the heat to low and simmer the syrup for a good 15-20 minutes, until it’s thickened a bit. After that, put the pan in the fridge to cool the syrup completely (or transfer the syrup into a little pitcher or bowl.) You want the syrup to be cold when you pour it on the fruit.

(You can make this the night before you need it!)

 
 
 
When you’re ready to assemble the fruit salad, wash all the fruit you want to use. Anything colorful and gorgeous-looking will do.

 
 
 
I did a bunch of strawberries…

 
 
 
And threw them into a big bowl.

 
 
 
Then halved a bunch of red grapes…

 
 
 
And threw them in with the strawberries.

 
 
 
Then did the same with green grapes, because they matched the bowl. And this is very important. Not really.

 
 
 
Blueberries sounded good, too!

 
 
 
Pour half of the cold syrup over the top…

 
 
 
Then toss the fruit gently to coat it in the rest of the syrup as you drizzle it in. You can’t really see it in the photos, but the tiny flecks of vanilla bean really make this look special.

 
 
 
Simply gorgeous!

 
 
 
But fresh mint makes it…

 
 
 
Well, simply gorgeous-er.

Hope you’re having a wonderful Holy Week, guys.

Here’s the handy dandy printable:

Recipe

Fruit Salad

Prep Time:
20 Minutes
Cook Time:
20 Minutes
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
12
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 1 cup Sugar
  • 1 cup Water
  • Juice Of 1 Orange
  • Zest Of 1 Orange
  • 2 whole Vanilla Beans, Caviar Scraped Out (or 2 Teaspoons Vanilla Extract)
  • 4 pints Strawberries, Hulled And Halved
  • 2 pints Blueberries
  • 2 cups Red Grapes, Halved
  • 2 cups Green Grapes, Havled
  • Mint Leaves

Preparation Instructions

Place the sugar, water, orange juice and orange zest into a small saucepan and stir to combine. Bring to a boil, then turn the heat to low and simmer for 15-20 to thicken slightly. Set aside to cool, then store in the fridge until cold.

Mix together all the fruit in a large bowl and pour the syrup over the top, tossing gently. Garnish with mint leaves and serve.

item.content:encoded:
I posted this photo on Confessions last week, and I got a few questions about what jeans I was wearing.

 
They’re “Skinny Kick” jeans from American Eagle, and I love them. They have a nice slim fit without being ridiculously tight and “skinny jean” skinny. (I burned out on skinny jeans months and months ago because they made me feel bad about myself. Ha.) These are more of a “real world” skinny jean with a little bit of an everyday style. (Please note: The model in this particular photo is probably six sizes smaller than me. But you can get a sense of the style of the jeans. The leg is slightly more flared at the bottom than this pic shows.)

Here are the pros and cons of Skinny Kicks.

PROS

* They have a nice stretch/give to them.

* They have a nice slightly flared leg without being crazy-flared or hippie looking. I can wear boots under the legs or I can wear flats. Both work.

* They’re somewhat slim through the hips and thighs but not tight.

* I love all three washes (the antique is my favorite, and it’s also the least expensive of the three.)

CONS

* They are just a leeeeeetle bit low-waisted. Definitely not in the crazy category of low-waisted—you know, the category that only .008% of the population can pull off. But if I’ve chowed down right before I wear them or haven’t done Pilates for a week, I always wish they had an extra inch or so. Still they’re not bad—I wear them all the time. I just have to stand up a little straighter when I wear them to keep the muffin top at bay.

* The dark blue wash (“Black Rock”) is so saturated, it does slightly rub off here and there. I only noticed it because when I first got a couple of pairs and wore them, I’d see a little bit of a dark blue hue to my fingertips. At first I thought I was dying. Then I realized it was the jeans.

Pros and cons weighed and analyzed, my verdict is that I love these jeans. I’ll keep wearing them for a long time!

Skinny Kick Jeans at American Eagle

Love,
P-Dub

Not an advertisement. Just sharing the jeans I like, man.

item.content:encoded:
Easter is coming, the goose is getting fat!

Wait. That’s Christmas.

And Christmas isn’t coming. At least not for 272 more days.

Okay, now that I’ve both confused and depressed everyone: Here’s the recipe for the yummy glazed ham I made on my show last Saturday—the same ham I’ll be making this Sunday for Easter brunch. It’s totally easy, exceedingly delicious, and results in a purty and glossy ham that’ll make your guests say “Oooooooh!” with wide, expectant eyes and, hopefully, hearty appetites because this ham could feed an army.

Here’s how I made it.

 
Get a big honkin’ bone-in ham. Fully cooked.

 
 
 
Use a really sharp knife to score a diamond pattern all over the surface of the ham: First cut lines in one direction…

 
 
 
Then cut in the other direction.

 
 
 
Grab a handful of cloves and poke them into the center of each diamond…

 
 
 
And keep going until the whole surface is dotted. I do this for looks more than flavor: I just think it looks lovely and traditional when it’s all done baking.

 
 
 
Cover the ham with foil, then put it into the oven to warm it up. I do 325 for at least 2 to 2 1/2 hours, but I’d say just look at the instructions on the package and follow those. Some hams say to go 3 to 4 hours, some at a lower temperature. The whole goal here is just to heat the ham slowly…and it takes awhile to do that.

 
 
 
While the ham is in the oven, you can make the glaze: Throw 3 cups of brown sugar into a saucepan…

 
 
 
Along with 1/2 cup of grainy, spicy mustard for a nice tang…

 
 
 
3 tablespoons apple cider vinegar for a little bite…

 
 
 
And the star of the show!

 
 
 
A whole can of Dr Pepper.

You can use Coke. Heck, you could probably even use root beer. But please, for the love of all things good and caramelized, do not use diet pop.

(It’s the sugar we’re after here.)

Amen.

 
 
 
Bring this mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat…

 
 
 
And simmer it for a good 15-20 minutes until it’s gotten darker and thicker.

 
 
 
After the ham has cooked for 1 1/2 to 2 hours, brush the surface with some of the glaze. Then pop it back into the oven, uncovered, for another 20 minutes or so.

 
 
 
Pull it out and brush on more glaze, then pop it back in the oven.

 
 
 
Then pull it out and brush on more glaze! Keep doing this until the ham is fully heated and the glaze is really gorgeous and glossy.

Note: On my Food Network episode last weekend, I only glazed it once because I had been at church and didn’t want to add too much more time before we ate. It was still totally delicious, but glazing the ham 2 or 3 (or 4) times really results in more of a masterpiece in terms of gorgeous surface.

 
 
 
Mmmm. Easter feast!

 
 
 
Enjoy, guys. This ham’ll take you far in life.

Here’s the handy printable!

Recipe

Glazed Easter Ham

Prep Time:
20 Minutes
Cook Time:
3 Hours
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
18
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 1 whole Fully Cooked Bone-in Ham (15-18 Pounds)
  • Whole Cloves
  • 3 cups Brown Sugar
  • 1/2 cup Spicy Brown Mustard
  • 1 can Dr Pepper Or Coke
  • 3 Tablespoons Apple Cider Vinegar

Preparation Instructions

Preheat the oven to 325 F.

Score the surface of the ham in a diamond pattern about 1/8-inch deep. Place cloves in the middle of each diamond. Place the ham in a large roasting pan with a rack, tent it with foil, and bake for 2 to 2/12 hours---or longer, depending on the package directions. (Some hams may require 3 to 3 1/2 hours at a lower temp; just check the package.)

Heat the brown sugar, mustard, vinegar and soda in a small saucepan until bubbly. Cook until reduced and a bit thicker, about 15 minutes.

After about 2 hours of baking time, remove the foil and brush the glaze on the ham in 20 minutes intervals (put the ham back in the oven, uncovered, in between) until it's nice and glossy. Remove from the oven and allow to rest 15-20 minutes before carving.

item.content:encoded:
First of all…

 
Luke’s photo is the winner of the Instagram contest!

 
 
 
Congratulations, Luke.

 
 
 
Matt, your horse photo was awesome. You were a very worthy opponent!

 
 
 
So was your grill photo, Mike!

I’ll stop shouting now!

Sheesh, Ree!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Sorry.

Anyway, the guys will all be hightailing it back to England soon.

I’ll miss the ol’ chaps.

But I’m going to be happy not to wear a mic for awhile. I’d like to go to the bathroom without unplugging first.

Sometimes I get stage fright.

You don’t want to know any more than that.

 
 
 
Yesterday I shot an entire show in one day, which is unusual. Typically, episodes take 1 1/2 to 2 days to shoot, but this one was basically shoot-as-it-happens. It was a freezer meal theme: I filled the freezer with lots of yummy food for busy days in my house, which is every day, and man, am I excited to have all this grub.

*Burp*

 
 
 
Here, Mike is rigging the freezer door so it won’t keep hitting me on the bottom as I stand and describe some of the things I’d stocked the freezer with.

It was getting a little embarrassing.

“This is a great freezer casserole. Really great flavor…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

“One thing I like to do is store grilled chicken breasts in airtight bags…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

“This is one of my favorite freezer soups. To make it, you…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

This is just another behind-the-scenes wrinkle you never think about when you watch cooking shows on TV: Freezer doors hitting the person on the bottom every time they try to talk.

It’s one of those things no one ever talks about.

 
 
This is my precious firstborn son. He makes my heart leap. I’ve been making him and his brother come hang out in my dressing room so I can listen to them talk about football and accuse them of eating all my snacks.

Man, can they polish off some snacks. Like, whole packages. Gone. Poof. As if the snacks ever existed.

 
 
 
I make Charlie come hang out in my dressing room, too.

 
 
 
It’s nice to walk in there and get a nice whiff of hound funk anytime I need a little pick-me-up.

Really keeps me going.

Or…not.

Have a happy Tuesday, everyone!
